titleStmt.title: Letters sent from Venice. Anno. 1571 Containing the certaine and true newes of the most noble victorie of the Christians ouer the armie of the great Turke: and the names of the lordes & gentlemen of the Christians slaine in the same battell. Translated out of the Frenche copie printed at Paris by Guille[...]d Niuerd, with the kings priuiledge.

titleStmt.title: Letters sent from Venice. Anno. 1571 Containing the certaine and true newes of the most noble victorie of the Christians ouer the armie of the great Turke: and the names of the lordes & gentlemen of the Christians slaine in the same battell. Translated out of the Frenche copie printed at Paris by Guille[...]d Niuerd, with the kings priuiledge.
titleStmt.author: Preuost, Fleuri.

publicationStmt.publisher: By Henrie Bynneman. And are to be sold in Paules churchyard by Anthonie Kitson,

notesStmt.note: Part 1 running title reads: The ouerthrow of of [sic] the Turkes.

Part 2 has separate title page, with same imprint, reading: The vvhole discourse of the victorie that it pleased God to giue to the Christians against the Turkes, and what losse hapned to the Christians in the said conduct. Englished by a Frenche copie printed at Paris, by Fleuri Preuost, priuiledged by the king.
Printer's device (McKerrow 138) on verso of C4, final leaf.
Print faded and show-through, and some pages stained; title pages marked, with some loss of print.
Reproduction of original in the British Library.

projectDesc.p: Created by converting TCP files to TEI P5 using tcp2tei.xsl, TEI @ Oxford.

editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: Containing the certaine and true newes of the mo≈øt Noble victorie of the Chri≈øtians ouer the armie of the great Turke: And the names of the Lordes & Gentlemen of the Chri≈øtians ≈ølaine in the ≈øame battell.
Tran≈ølated oute of the Frenche Copie Printed at Paris by Guille ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ de Niuerd, with the Kings Priuiledge.
Imprinted at London by Henrie Bynneman. And are to be ≈øold in Paules Churchyard by Anthonie Kit≈øon.

div.head: The ouerthrowe of the Turkes armie.
div.p:
THE Chri≈øten armie being in The≈ø≈øalonia, in the Hauen of Argo≈øtelly, and the enemy in the goulf of the Pante, they tooke adui≈øe what was be≈øt to b√©e doone. The Lorde Don Iean of Au≈øtrie thoughte it not good to enter into the goulfe, but the generall Biuier, and the Lord Iu≈øtinian Barbaric thought that be≈øte, earne≈øtly exhorting and per≈øuading to go into Bisterlo. For by this meanes (≈øay they) they ≈øhoulde obteyne the victory: and they concluded that Barbarico with eyght galeys ≈øhoulde goe to the entrie of the goulf, to a≈ø≈øay if he could trayne out the enemie: And whiles this was re≈øolued, the Generall Biuier was aduerti≈øed, that fiftie of the Turki≈øhe Galeys had lefte the armie, and were gone into Lenant. Whervpon the Lord Don Iean re≈øolued fully too enter the goulfe, and the ≈øixt of this moneth, being carried in Pregates, wente in per≈øone to
take order and encourage all men to b√©e ready on the morow to the battayle.

On Sunday the ≈øeuenth of October, was all the Armie in a readyne≈ø≈øe, the generall b√©eing in the midde≈øt with fifty galeys, on the right hande the Lord Barbarico, vpon the lefte the Ioerin, and the Dorian in the arreregard behauing him ≈øelfe verye valiantly. The ≈øixe greate≈øt Galeys rowed thr√©e on front, with .ij. little Galeys after them. Thus marched they in order, helped ≈øomwhat forwarde with a ≈ømall breathe, more fauourable to the enemie, and in good tyme di≈øcouered the other army, whiche came clu≈øtering lyke a wood, withoute any order. For they thought (as after was known) that ≈øo ≈øoone as they ≈øhoulde haue bene di≈øcryed, our armie would haue fled, and that they woulde be ready to ≈øpoyle and take ≈øome of our Galeys. But ≈øeing that the Chri≈øten armie made forwarde ≈øo boldly, they began to put them ≈øelues in aray, in fa≈øhion of an halfe Moone. Thus bothe the armies b√©eing approched within Cannon ≈øhot, the ≈øyxe greate galeys
did breake foorth, and pierced cleane thorough the Turki≈øhe armie, whiche they put in greate di≈øaray with their artillerie: whiche acte may be accompted the onely and chiefe cau≈øe of the victorie. In the di≈øcharge of the great ≈øhot, the Turkes were more galled than the Chri≈øtians. The Catholyke Generall, and the Venetian general, hauing betwene them the chiefe Ba≈ø≈øa, boorded his Galey, and tooke it, and hauing cutte off the Ba≈ø≈øaes head, put it vpon a pyke, which Don Iean helde in his hande, as a troph√©e. Ochiali Ba≈ø≈øa with his galeys pre≈ø≈øed ≈øore the left ≈øyde: and all the bodye of the enemies charged the body of the chri≈øtian battail, when Dorian with the arriergard ayded the ≈øayd body: and on the other ≈øide Don Iean ≈øente to ≈øuccour the lefte wing, an other number of Galeys, where there were alreadye ≈øeauen or eyght ∆≤enetian galeys. In this maner foughte they continually from morning til night. But in the ende the Chry≈øtians obteyned the victorie. There were taken .Clxxx. Galeys of the enimies, xxv. were burned, xv. ≈øoonke, xviij. fled, whom the Chri≈øtians
pur≈øued. The great Ba≈ø≈øa of Argier Gitride of the great Turke was founde dead. The Ba≈ø≈øa Ochiali fled with a fewe galeys. Fortua Ba≈ø≈øa was not found dead nor aliue. And the Ba≈ø≈øa whiche came in ≈øteade of Prely, is he whome before I haue ≈øhewed to haue ben taken & kylde. There are ≈ølayne .xx. thou≈øande Turks, v. thou≈øand Scarataui and .xiiij. thou≈øand Chri≈øtians pri≈øoners ≈øet at libertie. And they had taken into their armie to relieue them .xiiij. thou≈øande Spachi, whom they had leuied in Morea. The Chri≈øtians of Grece ≈øeing yt ≈ømal number of Turks left, & the whole ouerthrow giuen to the Turki≈øhe armie, began to ry≈øe. And ≈øo ≈øoone as the Chri≈øtian armie turned to Corfu, they with the victorie of Seigneur Don Iean, b√©eing accompanyed with a Fregate, came to the generall, offring to follow what part ≈øoeuer ≈øhall plea≈øe him to go, ≈øaying, to haue very wel knowne that the ∆≤enetians are chiefe lords of the ≈øea, but that neuer ≈øo wel tried as at that pre≈øent. It is maruellous, that in the ≈øix galeys which made the fyr≈øt point, were ≈ølayne but thr√©e per≈øons. And generally
thankes be to God, the whole fl√©ete hath had ≈ømall lo≈ø≈øe in re≈øpect of the great victorye.

God fauoured the Lord Barbarico ≈øo much, that he liued til night, when being aduerti≈øed of the a≈ø≈øured victorye, hie lifted vp hys handes too Heauen in token of ioy, and therewith y√©elded vp hys gho≈øte, being hurt in the eye with an Arrowe.

list.head: The names of the chri≈øtian Lords and Gentlemen ≈ølaine in the battaile.
list.item: The mo≈øte excellent Lorde, S. Augu≈øtine Barbarico.
The Magific Lord, S. Benet Laurence.
The Lord Ierome Contarin, vvith three of his Cou≈øins.
The Lord Anthonie de Mallogani Candiot.
The Lord Alexander Littico de Affrani.

div.p: THe magnifique Lanfran Iu≈øtinian brought the fir≈øt tidings of this glorious victorie this day at .vij. of the clocke in the morning, landing from oute of his galley at S. Markes. The Prince wente to m√©ete him, and at the fir≈øte gr√©eting the Lord Iu≈øtinian kn√©eling, ≈øaide: Mo≈øte excellente Prince, I bring vnto you the tidings of the Noble≈øt victorie that euer chri≈øtian men had. The Prince with his hands ≈øtretcht vp to heauen, thaÃÑked God, & without any ≈øtay with all the Nobilitie which clu≈øtered togither, went towarde the Church que≈øtioning with the ≈øayd L. Iu≈øtiman by the way, and there cau≈øed ≈øonges and Himnes to be ≈øung, pray≈øing God, and with greate deuotion remained aboue two houres in the Churche. The people and all the Nobles a≈ø≈øembled on euery ≈øide embra≈øing one an other, vttering all ≈øignes po≈ø≈øible of vnexpre≈ø≈øeable ioy.

THere is newes broughte that there is a ≈øhippe of Ragu≈øa that left Candie, the
thirtienth of September, which broughte newes that the Galliotte of Famagousta, in which was layde the munition, reported for certaine that the ≈øixte of that pre≈øente Moneth, the towne was in good e≈øtate and helde out lu≈øtily: Which if it b√©e ≈øo, the adui≈øe of Me≈ø≈øino of the fyfte day, which ≈øayd that the towne was lo≈øt from the beginnyng of Augu≈øte, is not true.
div.closer: Therfore, Vnto God be all honour and glorie.

div.head: The French King to the Bishop of Paris, vvith expre≈ø≈øe commaundement for Publike thankes to be giuen to God for the happie ≈øucce≈ø≈øe of the Christians againste the Turke.
div.p:
I am aduerti≈øed from my Emba≈ø≈øador re≈øident in ∆≤enice, of a happie victorie fallen vppon the Chri≈øtian armie by ≈øea again≈øte the Turkes, who being wholely vanqui≈øhed, left dead twentie thou≈øand bodies with one of their principall Ba≈øsaes, fiue thou≈øande taken pri≈øoners, a hundreth and .lxxx. Galleys taken, within the which were founde and ≈øet at libertie fourt√©ene thou≈øand captiues of chri≈øtians, and all this happening with a very little lo≈ø≈øe of the chri≈øtian armie, wherof I thought to giue you this ≈øp√©edie report, to the ende you might proc√©ede to giue God thankes, as well in oure ch√©efe churche of Paris, as in all other churches,
within your Dioce≈ø≈øe, with Proce≈ø≈øions and other ≈øuch plau≈øible actions of thanks giuing, as are conuenient to congratulate ≈øo happie a ≈øucce≈ø≈øe as it hathe plea≈øed the almightie to be≈øtowe vpon chri≈øtendom. And ≈øo my Lorde I pray God to pre≈øerue you in his holy grace.

closer.dateline: At Vantiour the la≈øt of October 1571.
closer.signed:
Signed.
CHARLES.
And vnder neath. BRVLART.

div.trailer: Vppon the indorcement is written. To my Lord of Paris, one of my priuie Councel, or to his Vicares or Deputies.

div.p: ¬∂ THE whole Di≈øcour≈øe of the Victorie that it plea≈øed God to giue to the Chri≈øtians again≈øt the Turkes, and what lo≈ø≈øe hapned to the Chri≈øtians in the ≈øaid conflict.
Engli≈øhed by a Frenche Copie Printed at Paris, by Fleuri Preuo≈øt, Priuiledged by the King.
Imprinted at London by Henrie Bynneman. And are to be ≈øold in Paules Churchyard by Anthonie Kit≈øon.

div.head: The whole and certein Di≈øcour≈øe of the victorie that it hath ple≈øed God to giue to the Chri≈øtians again≈øt the Turkes .vij. Octob. ANNO. 1571.
div.p:
THE diuine goodne≈ø≈øe and clemencie of the mercyful Lorde and God, hathe alwayes ben ≈øo pitifull and fauourable to ≈øuche as in their afflictions haue acknowledged him, that the remembrance thereof, dothe altogither make vs as it were perplexed and a≈øtonyed: for in all our actions and dooings w√©e haue ta≈øted and felte his clemencie and maruellous mercies, euen at the very houre when w√©e haue had lea≈øt hope thereof, as the wy≈øe man doth ≈øhew vs by the≈øe words: Men shall bee tickeled vvith an horrible fear, and euen vvhen they haue lea≈øt hope they shall maruel of their ≈øafetie. Wherof w√©e haue good experience, when that (be≈øides the innumerable graces w√©e receyue dayly) he dothe make vs more and
more to knowe his pui≈ø≈øance by ≈øuch effectes as to vs ≈ø√©emeth altogether impo≈ø≈øible, whiche oughte ≈øo muche the more to make vs prompt and ready to magnifie his greatne≈ø≈øe, to pray≈øe and exalt his holy name euerla≈øtyngly. And therfore his maruellous woorkes ought not to b√©e ≈øuppre≈ø≈øed or kepte in ≈øilence, but rather to b√©e publi≈øhed from nation to nation, that w√©e which depende vppon his goodne≈ø≈øe and mercie, maye render vnto him all honoure and pray≈øe for euer. The newes that is come to our knowledge, of the miraculous victorie that it hath plea≈øe ‚Ä¢ his diuine Maie≈øtie, to giue vnto the Armies o ‚Ä¢ the Emperour, of the Catholyke king, and of the Seigniorie of the ∆≤enetians, again≈øte the maruellous and in≈øupportable armie of the Turkes, for that cau≈øe is to be publi≈øhed to giue euery man aduerti≈øement therof by the di≈øcour≈øe that followeth.

By a Letter written from the Venetians bearing date the nynth day of October la≈øte, it was aduerti≈øed that the Sunday the ≈øeuenth of the ≈øayd moneth the armie generall of the Emperour, the
Catholike Kyng and of the Seignorie of the ∆≤enetians, were in Che≈øauian, within the portes of Argo≈øtoly: and the armie of the Turkes was within the gulphes of Velapante, looking when the Chri≈øtians ≈øhoulde come oute that they myght giue them battaile, and fight with them. The Chri≈øtians b√©eing but a few in numbre in re≈øpect of ≈øo great and in≈øupportable an armie as the Turks was (the which ≈ø√©emed rather lyke a Fore≈øt than a nauie on the ≈øea, being well nigh two hundred ≈øhippes and fiftie Foy≈øts,) made it ≈ø√©eme dangerous to enter within the goulfe to fight with them: for they were not equall in force to them.

The noble Don Iean de Austriche, (brother to the Catholike Kyng, and Lieutenant generall of his armie) was aduerti≈øed, that Fiftie of his greate Galeys were vnfurni≈øhed there where one parts of his force was: whyche gaue hym greate occa≈øion to haue the better wyll to fyghte with the re≈øte: To come to whiche purpo≈øe, h√©e ≈øent oute eyghte good Galeys to drawe oute the Turkes
to fight: After the which ‚Ä¢ yght „Äà‚óä„Äâ the re≈øte of our armie dyd follow in verye good order well furni≈øed (with good hope by the helpe of GOD to come to good effecte.) They did di≈øcouer the Armie of the Turkes, who perceyuing the Chri≈øtians dyd approche, came in great di≈øorder to a≈ø≈øayle them, tru≈øting onely in their forces: But the Chri≈øtians putting them≈øelues in battayle in forme of a Cre≈ø≈øent, did compa≈ø≈øe as well as they coulde, the Armie of the Turkes, and they did it in ≈øuche ≈øorte, (that by rea≈øon of the ≈øayde di≈øorder) after they hadde fought valyantly from eyght of the clock in the mornyng vntyll an houre after dynner, they b√©egan to obteyne victorie, whyche continued vntyll nyght: and if it had not bene for the darkne≈ø≈øe of the pouder and ≈øhotte, they had wholly defeated the armie of the Turkes, of the whiche there e≈øcaped but onely xviij. Galeys. Whyche victorie was executed wyth ≈øo ≈ømal a number on our part, that it was little or nothyng in re≈øpecte of ≈øuche and ≈øo great a victorie.

Aboute moue was taken the Galey of the Ba≈ø≈øa, (that was the Lieutenaunt generall of the Armie) who≈øe head was carryed to Seigneur Don Iean de An≈øtriche, whiche after he had a good while helde the ≈øame in his handes, h√©e commaunded it to b√©e put vppon the ende of a Pyke, and to be ≈øette vppon the for eparte of the Galley for victorie, and for a trymphe.

Of all the Armie of the Turkes, there was none ≈øauid but the ≈øayd .xviij. Galeys, whiche were folowed a greate whyle by thr√©e galeys of the Popes, four of the knyghtes of Malia, and ≈øixe of the ∆≤enetians, and they came ≈øo n√©ere them, that if the darkne≈ø≈øe of the nyght had not fauoured them with the helpe of their good Ores, they had not gone to carie the heauie newes of the ouerthrow of the re≈øt of their armie.
There is taken by the Chri≈øtians Cxxx. greate Turki≈øhe galeys and fyftie Foy≈øtes, oute of whiche Galleys and Foy≈øtes, haue bene deliuered xiiij. thou≈øand chri≈øtians captiues with the Turkes.
In the ≈øayde Galeys and foy≈øts was founde great ≈øtore of munitions of war, the mo≈øte parte whereof was deliuered to be ≈øente to Malta.
There was al≈øo .xv. Galeys of the Turkes drowned.
And there were .xxv. galeys burnt.
And there were .xx. thou≈øand Turks ≈ølayne wyth their Ba≈ø≈øa, whiche was the generall of their armie.
Be≈øydes fyue thou≈øande pri≈øoners.
The lo≈ø≈øe that the Chri≈øtians had, was two Galleyes of the Popes whiche were drowned.
And one burned of the Knightes of Malta.
Fiue of the ∆≤enetians were lo≈øte, of the which two were burnt and thr√©e drouned.
The generall of the armie of the ∆≤enetians, was ≈ølaine in the ≈øaide Galleys that were lo≈øt, and .xx. ∆≤enetian Gentlemen.

There is deade of the Chri≈øtians as wel out of the ≈øaid eight Galeys that were lo≈øt, as of them that were ≈ølayne in the
other Galleys, aboute two thou≈øande men, of the which there were foure Knightes of Malta, thr√©e Spaniardes, and one Italian.
The Venetians amongs all the re≈øt did ≈øhewe them≈øelues very valyante, and they were the fir≈øt that with great furie did ioyne in combate agayn≈øt the ≈øayde Turkes.

div.head: To the Chri≈øtian Reader.
div.p:
beholde heere that whiche may he faithfully vnder≈øt ‚Ä¢‚Ä¢ d by the letter written from ∆≤enice the .ix. of October la≈øt, of the victorie yt it hath plea≈øed our good God to giue vs again≈øt the enimies of ye holy Church. Therfore con≈øidering the times pa≈øt and pre≈øent, in the which God all mercifull, hathe deliuered and pre≈øerued vs from a number of mi≈øch√©eues and daungers, with the which we ordinarily are be≈øet, without hauing any power of oure ≈øelfe, to e≈øcape the ≈øame, except the imme≈øurable pitie of oure Lord God ≈øhoulde helpe vs. We ought therefore to ≈øing continually with the royall Prophet, the earthe is all repleni≈øhed with the mercie of our good God which dothe maintaine vs in his kingdom, in his faith, in his ≈øeruice and in his grace incomprehen≈øible: and
let vs firmely bel√©eue that he hathe care of vs, and that he dothe k√©epe and defend vs more warely than the Egle or the Henne doo their chickens. Let vs giue him therefore withoute cea≈ø≈øing, glorie, and prei≈øes euerla≈øting, framing our ≈øelues to maruell at the greatne≈ø≈øe of his mercie, that doth pre≈øerue vs alwayes from eminent dangers and perilles.

figure.head: ARMIPOTENTI ANGLIAE
figure.figDesc: depiction of a draped female figure on a pedestal, holding the bridle of a rearing horse in each hand
